claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.
explanation: The image consists of multiple box-and-whisker plots showing hemagglutination inhibition (HI) antibody titers (log₂ scale) measured at Day 0 and 1 month post-vaccination for four influenza strains (A(H3N2), A(H1N1)pdm09, B/Victoria, B/Yamagata). Data are stratified by seven repeat vaccination arms combining egg- and cell-propagated vaccines (e.g., cell–cell, cell–RIV4, RIV4–cell, RIV4–RIV4, IIV4–cell, IIV4–RIV4, IIV4–IIV4). Geometric mean titers with 95% confidence intervals are shown, and significant differences (p-values) between responses to cell- versus egg-propagated antigens are annotated. The figure presents immunogenicity data comparing antibody responses to cell- versus egg-propagated vaccine viruses but provides no direct evidence of mutations arising during vaccine production. Thus, it does not support the claim. Note: No direct mutation or genetic sequencing data are shown; inference about production-related mutations is not directly evidenced in this figure.
